section: Client agrees to pay to Company to design and develop a website for Client (the "Client Website") in accordance with the accompanying Scope of Work, attached to this Agreement as Exhibit A.
explanation: The phrase 'in accordance with the accompanying Scope of Work' suggests that the Scope of Work (Exhibit A) should provide detailed specifications and requirements for the website design and development. However, Exhibit A is very general and does not provide specific details, leading to potential disputes about what constitutes 'in accordance with'.

section: Any changes to the Scope of Work following the execution of this Agreement requiring Additional Work must be submitted to and accepted by Company in writing as a "Change Order". Additional Work shall be defined as the addition or revision of pages, graphics, or other features, any text, graphic or page design or programming requiring more than two rounds of textual or graphical revisions, substantial revisions to text and/or content provided by Client, changes to elements which have been finalized, or significant changes in the Scope of Work.
explanation: The definition of "Additional Work" is broad and contains subjective terms like 'substantial revisions' and 'significant changes.' This lack of precision can lead to disagreements about whether specific changes fall under the definition of Additional Work, creating ambiguity and potential disputes.

section: Terms of the project: 12 weeks from February 8, 2018 to May 3, 2018.
explanation: This section states that the terms of the project are 12 weeks beginning on February 8, 2018 and ending on May 3, 2018. However, 12 weeks from February 8, 2018 would end on May 3, 2018. The exact length of the term is unclear.

section: Client shall make a prepayment of $1,900 and pay the remaining $3,100 on completion of the Scope of Work.
explanation: The phrase 'on completion of the Scope of Work' is vague and does not provide a clear and objective trigger for when the final payment is due. It is not clear what constitutes the completion of the Scope of Work, leaving it open to interpretation and disagreement. For example, what happens if the client is not happy with the completed work.

section: Company representatives are available during Company's normal business hours which are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. UTC +2, Monday through Friday. Any email or telephone correspondence received after normal business hours will be processed the following business day.
explanation: The term 'processed the following business day' is vague. It is not clear when exactly the emails or telephone correspondence received after normal business hours will be completed and/or replied to the following business day.

section: Client shall pay an additional surcharge for any services requiring work to be performed outside of normal business hours by reason of a rush deadline requested by Client or as a result of Client's failure to meet scheduled times for delivery and/or review and approval of information, content and materials. The surcharge for rush work shall be the hourly rate plus twenty-five percent (25%).
explanation: It is not stated what the hourly rate is and this makes it difficult to accurately calculate the surcharge for rush work

section: Company at its sole discretion may at any time alter or cease providing the Customer Service which it has agreed to provide to Client relating to Client Website pursuant to this Agreement without any liability to Company.
explanation: This clause gives the Company the right to unilaterally cease providing customer service at any time without liability. This significantly undermines the value of the customer service provision and could be considered unconscionable, especially if customer service is essential for the website's functionality. Depending on applicable consumer protection laws, such a clause might be deemed unenforceable or require specific disclaimers.

section: Development of design of Free Cook Stage 1: 1. Search for competitors, collecting additional information on the subject. 2. Development of unique style of the Client Website. 3. Development of a logo based on the unique corporate style. 4. Designing UI/UX-practical parts. 5. Development of the main and internal pages of the Client Website. Stage 2: 6. Emotional design (creation of web-assistants). 7. Adaptive design (mobile version of the Client Website). 8. Design adaptation to other languages. 9. Development of a prototype and interface testing. Stage 3: 10. Search Engine Optimization.
explanation: The scope of work is vague and lacks specific deliverables. For example, 'Development of a unique style of the Client Website' is subjective and open to interpretation. There are no clear metrics or acceptance criteria defined, making it difficult to determine whether the work meets the client's expectations or is considered complete.
